Fields.DialogueText: Looks like the Morgana activity in this sector isn't decreasing.
It's on the rise. As long as we hack at the leaves, the roots will continue to spread.
Well, what's to be done about it? Let's continue on.
Do you ever wonder that, Kapitan? What we are meant to do?

Fields.MenuText: We fight the Morganas. Simple as that.
I try to keep my mind on the mission, but I wonder about the war as a whole.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm afraid it is not so simple, Kapitan.
Do you think this war can end well?
The more I really think about this war, the more hopeless things seem.
*ALARM*
Make ready.
As ever.
And Chervona, don't carry so much on your shoulders. We'll be fine.
Of course. Sometimes you don't see a way forward until you feel you've gone blind.
@BATTLE
Chervona, what is that in the distance?
It appears to be debris, Kapitan... and Morganas.
There could be survivors. Move to intercept.
Whatever it takes for whoever we can save.
@BATTLE
Kapitan, three survivors have been brought on board.

Fields.MenuText: Why did the Morgana attack them?

Fields.DialogueText: They are barely conscious, but they should recover.
They didn't say. They are badly hurt.
I couldn't tell. They appeared delusional. I can't blame them.
Did they say anything at all about what happened?
Some of the medical personnel are taking notes on their ramblings. They said something about... the Caleuche.
Who?
A ghost ship. The crew must have picked the story up during our stop in Valparaíso.
Can you put a stop to it? We don't need any more ghost stories than we get from the Morganas.
That's a risky move, Kapitan. Forbidding discussion may give the impression that we fear this Caleuche.
So we're to fight whatever they're whispering about, even though we don't know what it is.
It seems to have worked with the Morganas so far.
Well, you Belles know the Morganas.
To an extent. They have potential we can scarcely imagine.
Fortunately, so do you.
Da! I look forward to unlocking it together.
Kapitan, we have received rendezvous coordinates from the survivors' comrades.
Where are we meant to take them?
There is a friendly merchant ship just a few-
*ALARM*
I doubt they want us to bring friends.
Breach of etiquette.
Then let's hurry. We don't want to be late.
@BATTLE
Have all of the survivors been transferred?
Every one.
Good. Let's get out of here.
Something is troubling you.

Fields.MenuText: I just don't like being lied to.
I was wondering about what actually happened to them.
Just don't want to push my luck if there's a ghost ship about.

Fields.DialogueText: You think they were lying about the Caleuche?
You mean if they were attacked by a phantom vessel?
Kapitan, have you been listening to the crew's ghost stories?
What do you think of their explanation?
It does not make sense, but it does not have to.
Huh. I've heard of false flag attacks, but it just seems impossible that someone would make up a ghost story to cover up some kind of scheme.
The presence of the Morganas has changed that arithmetic, Kapitan. But I attended to them in the infirmary. Whatever attacked these people, it hurt them badly.
They were lucky to find you.
Lucky to find us, Kapitan. I can't do this alone. Nor would I choose to.
You know, Chervona, this Caleuche doesn't sound like a bad assignment.
What are you on about, Kapitan?
I've been doing some research in our off time. Have you read this book we had below?
Spirits of the Seas? I've read it.
The Caleuche sounds fun. Constant music, people laughing...
Gathering the souls of the drowned.
Someone has to do it.
Do you believe in such things?
Hmmm. I agree.
Really?
Maybe not as strongly as you.
My point stands. Even if the Caleuche was real, it wouldn't go around attacking merchant ships.
Ghost ship or no, they were lying?
That's what the evidence points to.
*ALARM*
Our evidence is circumstantial, and the circumstances are relayed to us by terrified and injured people. If I were you, I'd call off the ghost hunt and listen closer to them.
Ever the practical Belle.
@BATTLE
Can't help the way I'm built, Kapitan. Better than these Morganas, for a start.
Chervona, change course and head for that large smoke cloud.
What is it?
I'm not sure. The smoke's obscuring the view.
*ALARM*
Morganas, Kapitan, on an intercept course.
Let's push through them. We'll get as close to the smoke as possible without impairing visibility.
@BATTLE
Clear seas. For now.
Chervona, look. There, in the smoke.
Kapitan?
Does it have sails?
Civilian, then?
I've chided you before about jumping to conclusions.
Damn! It's disappearing into the smoke.
Should I pursue?
No, not through that. We'll investigate later.
Imagine that.
Let me know when we're to do that. I want to spend a little more time with our guests.
Are they starting to come around?
It's going to take some time yet. But time is something I have an abundance of. I owe it to them.
What did you find out?
There is no way a ship from the Caleuche's time period would have the armament to create the destruction we've seen.
I thought as much.
From the time period she's purported to be from, of course. One would think she'd evolve the way the Morganas do.
Think this is all just a silly misunderstanding?
I think the circumstances are strange and worth looking into. But I draw the line at superstition.

Fields.MenuText: Do you think the Morganas are destroying the ships?
Could the ship not be as old as it looks?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, but that doesn't explain the appropriation of the legend. Morganas aren't exactly subtle.
Anyone can build a barque.
Line. Drawn.
*ALARM*
Here is an adversary we are at least familiar with.
I prefer to focus on the here and now, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
How long until the future becomes the here and now?
I wish I had the luxury of dwelling on such things. Humans...
Should I be insulted?
Forgive me if I overstepped. I'm genuinely intrigued.
Kapitan, we are receiving a distress call.
From whom?
A merchant ship. It seems to be from the same group we met earlier.
What's their status?
They say they're under attack from... the Caleuche. Ugh.
*ALARM*
And we've also got Morganas to deal with.

Fields.MenuText: Ignore them and head towards the distress call.
Attack the Morganas, then head towards the distress call.

Fields.DialogueText: Nemozhlyvo. We can't outrun them.
We've no other option.
Unleashing hell, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
This was the last source of the distress call?
Regrettably. That last battle appears to have kept us just long enough.
And there were no survivors in the wreckage?
I've already ordered the crew to stop the search efforts. Whatever that merchant ship was running from, it succeeded.
What is going on here?
Kapitan, we have received a request from some of the local merchants.
Yes?
They want us to escort them.

Fields.MenuText: I wish we could, but we can't abandon our post.
You don't think that'll bring the Caleuche back to us?

Fields.DialogueText: But would we not have a better chance of finding the attacker?
The Morganas tend to seek us out. Command will understand if we make the case.
If we don't draw out their attackers, they will at least be safe.
You're right. Set up an escort for us.
Of course. Our victory would be hollow if there were nothing to return to afterward.
*ALARM*
I wonder if they will be safer with us.
@BATTLE
I am a Belle, Kapitan. There is nowhere safer than within fifty kilometers of me.
Yes, yes, you're very powerful.
Thank you, Kapitan.
I was being facetious.
Only a little bit.
No sign of any trouble yet. Is the convoy still with us?
Affirmative. We should reach our destination soon.
Then this would have been a waste of time.
*ALARM*
What is it?
Proof that this was not a waste of time.
You're enjoying this, aren't you?
Smugness is not in my nature, Kapitan.
Right. Move to intercept.
@BATTLE
I've had a cable from the ship we escorted, Kapitan. They send their gratitude.

Fields.MenuText: It could have been a little more exciting.

Fields.DialogueText: Not if we saved lives.
Such recklessness is unbecoming. Would you be so cavalier about the Morganas?
Even if we didn't find the mystery ship.
I think it's worth another try. Let's set up another escort.
You know I'm always in favor of defending the defenseless. But I can't help but wonder if you're not looking for something.
... Although if it were, I'd be reveling in it.
I wonder if this might not put your little ghost story to rest. What would a ghost have to fear from us?
I haven't a clue what you're talking about.
Kapitan. I will not question our results. But your motives are suspect.
So is the prospect of a haunted ocean.
I can't decide whether your heart's in the right place or in a very wrong one.
Two signals, Kapitan. Fast approach.
They're heading towards this merchant ship.
Smoke, Kapitan, as before. And some of the Morganas appear to be breaking off.
No. They are heading into the smoke.
They are moving to attack.
They are attacking the ship in the smoke.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
It seems ghosts don't agree on everything.
I was beginning to think you'd never come around.
I haven't. But whatever was in the smoke managed to drive the Morganas off.
Then why didn't they come after the ship?
Even Morganas assess risk. I suspect they wanted to live to fight sooner.
Do we have allies out there... or enemies?
One thing at a time, Kapitan. We will strike back if struck.
Kapitan, the merchants want to know when the next escort will be.
See, that's what I was trying to avoid. We won't be doing one. They can't keep relying on us.
A foreseeable consequence of your little ghost hunt.
That's not what it-
*ALARM*
Speaking of which...
Bring us around.
@BATTLE
I'll inform the merchants now.

Fields.MenuText: Would you attempt to help them in finding safer routes?

Fields.DialogueText: That's the aim. There's only so much Chile can do for them.
I will, Kapitan. With as much regret as I can muster.
If it were up to me, you'd be the one doing this.
Are you mad at me?
I'm disappointed, Kapitan. You're letting the crew's ghost stories get to you. It's crippling our assignment.
If there's a supernatural danger here in the south Pacific-
Then we treat it as any other enemy! We respond to reports of Morgana activity. We don't guard shipments of luxury goods on the off chance that the Flying Dutchman might show up.
How did you know about-
I read all their manifests, Kapitan. The merchants were practically falling over themselves to talk to me.
I didn't.
So it's not just superstition. It's carelessness besides.
Chervona, those merchants would have-
Enough. You deserve better than my anger. Let me process it.
Kapitan.
Unusual? From who?
It claims to be from the kapitan of the Caleuche.
Don't make me say it again.
Yes, yes, bask in it.
Against my preferences, I think it prudent that we find out.
A piece of paper in a bottle? How did this get here?
A small vessel pulled to our side and signaled us. They left before we could react.
The note reads... "Captain, you know not what you do. I have a story for you, if you'll follow my clue".
Which clue is... coordinates. A bit on the nose for ghost pirates, or whatever.
And why would we go to those coordinates?
*ALARM*
Starting now.
Let's go.
@BATTLE
Chervona.
I hope I was not too out of line in our last dispute. I impugned your judgment.
You're the Belle, Chervona. If anyone's equipped to question the captain's judgment, it's the ship.
Thank you, Kapitan. I still have questions, though not from you. They throw things into a new light. This letter arrived... a rather unusual one.
It goes on to name specific ports we've served as targets. It may be simple tomfoolery, Kapitan, but we must treat it as an emergency.
Another message in a bottle?
And I thought you were the childish one.
I'm going to ignore that. Was it as poetic as the last?
No, it's quite plain: "Captain, I am the leader of a group fighting corruption in our home waters. My message is in pieces to avoid interception. Caleuche is a ruse."

Fields.MenuText: What do you make of this?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know many who would.
Just coordinates.
It's an odd tactic; some might say foolish. But not unheard of.
Well, if there are coordinates on there, let's follow them.
You have a mystery to solve?
*ALARM*
I have a coastline to protect from an unknown quantity.
I couldn't agree more.
@BATTLE
Morganas. Just as we suspected.
I suspected they might be near the coordinates. It's hard to communicate these days without them listening in.
Don't shoot the bottle if it's in there.
This is turning into a fantasy story, Kapitan. How do you propose we do that?
I'll be careful, but no promises.
Thank you for acknowledging my expertise.
Honestly, do you take me for one of those trigger-happy Gnevny-classes?
@BATTLE
The message was recovered safely.
Well?
"Captain, my ship is modern yet disguised as the Caleuche. My fleet has three submarines. We create a smoke screen to hide the battle."
Why all the theatrics?
How do you disguise yourself as a ship whose very appearance is the subject of debate?
This isn't right. Even if they're not doing anything wrong, we need to minimize variables out here.
Rugged individuals can be so tiresome. They haven't given us any reason for their actions.
No, they haven't. Let's find the next message.
Under whose authority would we even apprehend them?
Nobody's. It's their right to be reckless.
The tyranny of the self...
This is starting to remind me of Inna's games.
What does this new one say?
It explains what they are doing... to an extent.
Well?
"Captain, the merchants you have helped are criminals. They smuggle from our country. Many have died. We will stop them."

Fields.MenuText: We would need proof of that.
I knew they were lying about something.

Fields.DialogueText: It's their word against another's. It's not our place to judge.
That isn't a decision we're equipped to make.
Or this person could be. It's not our fight and never has been.
Were there coordinates again?
Like it was written by some bourgeois tastemaker.
*ALARM*
Hopefully we can wrap this up.
Our mission could be so important. And yet...
@BATTLE
We're defending the common man from Morganas, Chervona. It doesn't matter who's telling the truth.
That is... remarkably clearsighted, Kapitan. They might not even have lived to send this message were it not for us.
Does this mean we see eye to eye now?
... After a fashion. I can approve of our results while strongly rebuking the path we followed to get there.
Where's your idealism?
Stuffed tightly in the barrel of one of my 21-Ks. I saved it for these Morganas.
Kapitan, here is the last message.
What makes you say that?
There are no coordinates on this one. I read the occasional pirate story, too.
Kapitan, the merchants are wealthy. Their crew is superstitious. They will eventually flee because of us. Do not help them.

Fields.MenuText: We can't just let these people keep fighting among themselves while there's an apocalypse on.
We stop the merchants here and now.
It's a little late to leave them to their own devices.

Fields.DialogueText: Belles were not put on this earth to save humans from themselves. And yet...
By any means necessary.
Nothing for all this but to punch through the other side of it.
*ALARM*
Much as I appreciate the opportunity for philosophy...
Criminals versus fake ghosts. Why could the merchants not challenge their enemies on the strength of their honesty?
Perhaps they wanted to appeal to something deeper.
@BATTLE
Perhaps they simply wanted to beat their colleagues at their own game.
We'll let them fight it out just as soon as we've dealt with the threat they can't.
I've decided we need to look into the merchants we helped.
May I ask why?

Fields.MenuText: Because I don't know how to find the Caleuche.
Because that would solve both of our problems.

Fields.DialogueText: Welcome to my world.
Very funny. If that means you've stopped playing their games, I welcome you with open arms.
If the smugglers stop, the Caleuche stops too.
Would you invite them to a convoy I am hosting?
An escort?
We can't legally stop and search them without grounds. However, if lead the convoy I am entitled to search every vessel.
I shouldn't make that part obvious?
Try not to.
*ALARM*
Let me clear my mind with some battle. It seems you've hit upon the solution at last.
High praise.
@BATTLE
The highest. Even I can lose myself in frustration.
The merchants have agreed to the convoy.
I thought they might respond well to you.
If novelty be a weapon, I will gladly empty the clip. They are waiting on your final approval.
*ALARM*
Looks like we will be delayed.
Fruitfully.
@BATTLE
Do you think it's right, tricking them like this?
No.

Fields.MenuText: No, just come out and say it.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, but you are not wrong.
I don't mean it as an insult.
It is wrong, but you are less wrong.
What do you mean?
I thought they were suspicious too, and you have enough reason. You did what you had to do.
Yeah.
But you're a good person. That's why you feel a little slimy. You're fine.
Two wrongs make a right, eh?
Don't focus on the principle. Such things change with the world order. What did you want?
... I'd be lying if I said the thought of a ghost ship didn't intrigue me.
I knew it.
You knew it. But letting these people fight when they were all threatened... it just didn't sit right with me.
Hmm.
Hmm?
I believe in letting people make their own mistakes, Kapitan. Even if we are all stronger together. But there is still a place for mercy, to an extent.
To what extent?
I pray I never find out.
They don't seem very happy about having their ships searched.
I don't blame them. We've already found enough to make me want to drop them in the bottom of the ocean.
Medical supplies, food... all bound for the black market.
*ALARM*
I'm surprised that this is improving my mood.
We need to keep an eye on these smugglers and drive off the Morganas.
I'd almost rather we did the reverse.
@BATTLE
The last of the ships have been searched and the crews detained. That's our good deed for the week.
In my next after action report, pending your edits.
Da. I do not envy them their sentences.
Let's not join in their larceny, Kapitan.
Either way, we've done our part.
I'm glad we found them out. We actually helped them.
The smugglers?
Everyone. The merchants don't have to keep up this expensive charade. The smugglers don't have to expose themselves to the risk of Morgana attacks.
I suppose a prison is safe.
An inland one.
I'm not sure I find that funny.
That was a bit ghoulish, wasn't it? Forgive me, Kapitan. The Revolution has no place for thieves.
We have a distress call from a civilian ship.
Morganas?
According to the call... the Caleuche.

Fields.MenuText: What? How did they not find out?

Fields.DialogueText: Different civilians. They weren't exposed to the ridiculous conspiracy.
They are continuing the fight. They must be desperate.
No zealot like the recent convert...
*ALARM*
Morganas.
They are blocking our way.
Make ready to punch through.
Think this is another ruse?
@BATTLE
You're still raw about those smugglers we took on.
To be otherwise would make me a hypocrite.
Kapitan, I believe that if we tweak the sensitivity of our sonar, we can find the submarines in the Caleuche fleet.
Good, but if we try to escort again, they will just avoid us.
We need to find a way to get behind them.

Fields.MenuText: Contact command and see if we can get some help.
See if you can find out anything about them.
Would you put together a record of the tactics they are using?

Fields.DialogueText: I'll emphasize the importance of the issue.
It'll be hard to find a ghost, Kapitan.
I've been doing that since the day we encountered them.
They're slippery.
Indeed, but they underestimate you.
They underestimate us.
You and I?
*ALARM*
Kapitan... I couldn't agree more. My confidence in the upcoming battle is renewed.
@BATTLE
And the crew. You need someone to maintain you and I need someone to carry out our strategic objectives. This is bigger than any of us.
Chervona, I just got word from command.
Good word?
What did they say?
I don't understand.
With what?
We've been ordered to stop interfering with the merchants and their affairs.
That's fine, they have... They haven't stopped smuggling.
It would appear so.
Then what is going on?
It's political; they aren't calling it smuggling, per se. Command is doing what they can, but right now our hands are tied.
What are we to do?
*ALARM*
We continue pushing back the Morganas in this section. We'll figure something out.
@BATTLE
Not every corner of the world can be prepared for revolution at once. Scarcity is one hell of a drug.
Morganas, there. Let's take them out so we can head to port.
I'll put some extra fire into these volleys.
@BATTLE
So all of the crew understands what to do?
They do, but this plan does seem...
Ridiculous, yes, a little.
Ghost stories, Kapitan? At long last, are we still here?

Fields.MenuText: The captain of the Caleuche said they were superstitious.

Fields.DialogueText: It won't work.
We will see.
He also pretends to command the boat of the dead.
Either way, most of these merchants make port here. That means they frequent these pubs.
Again, Kapitan, you do not need to convince me this isn't an excuse to give your crew shore leave.
Maybe it was an excuse to get you out for once.
I need no excuse for that, but remember I cannot leave the ship.
Then let's go spread some rumors.
Chervona, I've been in close contact with Command.
Any news?
The companies associated with the smuggling are losing their support. They feel like the situation will be resolved soon.
Thank you for staying involved.

Fields.MenuText: I think we all know that the ghost stories are what brought them down.
You don't need to add the ghost stories to your report.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, yes, Kapitan, common knowledge.
Honestly? I wouldn't count on them every time.
Already there, in ink. Frankness is a prerequisite.
Maybe it was just an excuse to give the crew a break.
I did hear a rumor that the companies were having trouble finding crews.
You did?
Rumors again. Pay them no mind.
*ALARM*
Set course. Once we're done here I might have a pleasant surprise for you.
A surprise?
@BATTLE
Call it a hunch. I think we both earned it.
Chervona, I have our new orders and I think you're going to be interested.
A transport mission? Civilians?
Yes, well, it's a short cruise.
Kapitan, I am not a leisure vessel to ferry people around!
That's exactly what I said, and the manifest had only one passenger, but he insisted. A Stepan Osipovich Makarov?
He's been dead for decades. Who's using his name?
Some higher-up in the Soviet government. It seems he knew how to get your attention.
The Admiral!? Kapitan! ... I'm going to faint.
*ALARM*
Faint later. We've got Morganas incoming.
Shaking it off. Kapitan, thank you, thank you so much!
Made the arrangements months ago. He's not the easiest to get a hold of.
I did not know you thought about me so much.
I do keep track, you know.
You too?
Whatever his name is, it rhymes with "Kuznetsov."
@BATTLE
Ni, Kapitan. I wouldn't share it with anyone but you!
He's only one of the greatest military purge survivors! Who knows how many good men he saved?
Yes, I... Wait. What do you mean "You too?"
Motives. Desires. Plans. I'll have to show you the book I keep yours in. It's the story of one who doesn't let people die where it can be helped.
I learned it by watching you.
My, Kapitan, aren't we forward?
Is it working?
You solved the mystery of the Caleuche that way. Who's to say it won't work a second time? Now, come here.
